Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Customized Manufacture of Protective Headgear for Mitigation of Fall Related Injuries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in the ability to manufacture customized non-stigmatizing, attractive headgear containing advanced materials to provide protection in older adults from head injury as a result from a fall. Injury from falls is a severe and growing problem with the personal consequence of potential severe injury and economic consequences to individuals, families and the healthcare system. Initially targeted to older adults, this product can be used by persons who seek to stay active without the fear of injury from falling. The commercial product is an aesthetic design that relies on custom fit eliminating unsightly chinstraps typically found in impact resistant helmets. Manufacturing success will lead to development of other protective devices such as hip protectors and then for other susceptible body parts (wrists/elbows). Commercial success will be sales to individuals, active retirement communities, nursing homes and hospitals. Further success can be defined by the ability to license the technology and manufacturing process to leaders in other industries such as active sports including football, hockey, skiing and extreme sports. With this STTR, the manufacturing design methods will also provide hands-on experience to engineering students that can be applied to other projects in their careers.



This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project will design a customizable, small batch manufacturing system for protective headgear to mitigate the impact from falls. The direct medical cost of falls is estimated at $30.0 billion. Customized and automated manufacturing of the headgear will alleviate the concerns highlighted in the previous compliance trials that indicated goodness of fit is essential to a marketable headgear product. This effort will solidify our ability to manufacture a non-stigmatizing headgear design in a cost-effective manner. Research objectives include quantifying parameters for a customized fit, designing and developing the automated manufacturing system for a product tailored to the individual. The research plan includes using state-of-the-art techniques in image capture and testing of the automation/customization scheme. Automation of the process will control the shape and material details of the product. Another task will evaluate the inclusion of 3-D printing as its capability is quickly maturing and it has the potential to create fully customized headgear. Phase I anticipated results include an operational version of a CAD front end system to capture head piece parameters and the design of a small batch manufacturing system to be built in Phase II.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Alba-Technic project team is developing a headgear product named SMARTY® to protect fall prone elderly from brain injury. According to the U.S. Center for Disease Control (CDC) in a study published in the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, more than one third of adults 65 and older fall each year in the United States, with falls being the most common cause of traumatic brain injury (TBI). Every year, between 700,000 and 1.0 million patients suffer a fall during their hospital stay (Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality), and the average increase in hospital operational costs due to these fall injuries exceeds $13,000 and patient lengths of hospital stay increases by an average of 6.27 days. With the average charges for a TBI hospitalization at about $17,500, this represents more than $1 billion in direct hospital expenses that in today’s cost driven health care marketplace hospitals are hard pressed to ignore.

 Although the need is evident for fall protection headgear, implementation has been less than optimal. There are three major issues with products currently marketed for fall impact protection to protect the elderly from fall related TBI – efficacy, attractiveness and comfort. The majority of existing headgear are proven to be unattractive and uncomfortable thus significantly reducing the likelihood of compliance.   

Our team has developed a fall protection headgear design solving these issues and the Alba-Technic SMARTY headgear was created to be attractive and comfortable with a custom fit to increase compliance. The efficacy of a head protection device primarily depends on two factors: the quality of the shock absorbing material and the goodness of fit, especially if no chinstrap is used. The effectiveness of headgear in mitigating fall impact is accomplished through the Alba-Technic patented impact resistant system, EV02 that is a combination of a dilatant and honeycomb material. Upon impact the dilatant material stiffens so that it distributes (shunts) forces over a wider area of the honeycomb material that in-turn responds to the loading in a nonlinear manner by buckling. A custom fit eliminates the need for a chinstrap enhancing comfort and improving the appearance.

The goal of this Phase I STTR was to create a small batch manufacturing method that results in a customized fit product for the Alba-Technic SMARTY fall protection headgear. The value of a product like SMARTY was assessed for fall protection in the elderly population during prior research conducted by Dr. Steve Castle of our research team in 2013. One major conclusion of Dr. Castle’s study was that having a custom fit product enhances aesthetics and comfort and results in a more highly desirable item. Once this critical need for non-stigmatizing fall protection headgear was ascertained, the team sought this NSF Phase I award to create a manufacturing methodology that would effectively and efficiently produce the SMARTY product. A process method was developed where the impact-resisting skeleton conforms to the shape of an individual’s head at a reasonable manufacturing cost. Our Phase I effort has established a process to manufacture custom shaped headgear that requires a confluence of advanced manufacturing techniques including 3D printed tooling and image capture techniques to capture the shape of the customer’s head and to insure proper sizing. Significant advances were made in both of these aspects during Phase I. The manufacturing system and a viable methodology for manufacture of SMARTY was proven along with several enhancements to the SMARTY design such as creating a single curved custom fit unit by molding methods that uses tooling created by compound curved 3D printing techniques.
